title: Secure the future: LPAs give you power to control your life, says Harvey Jones
text:
Secure the future: LPAs give you power to control your life, says Harvey Jones Secure the future: LPAs give you power to control your life, says Harvey Jones Nobody likes to think about dementia before it happens but you can pay the price for failing to act. PUBLISHED: 17:43, Tue, Aug 4, 2015 | UPDATED: 17:52, Tue, Aug 4, 2015 GETTY TRUST: Talk it over with loved ones 
Every year, thousands of families face a costly legal battle to take charge of a loved one’s affairs because they failed to set up a lasting power of attorney (LPA) in advance. 
An LPA gives family or friends the power to make decisions about your property and finances if you are unable to do so, say, after suffering Alzheimer’s or losing your mental capacity for any other reason. 
Younger people should also consider setting up an LPA, known as a continuing power of attorney in Scotland, in case a major illness or serious injury prevents them from managing their own affairs. 
If you don’t set up an LPA, you have no power over who is appointed to look after your health and finances. 
Sarah Cash, head of the tax, trusts and estates team at law firm Hugh James says: “Appointing an LPA while you are in good health helps to ensure your finances aren’t placed under the control of someone you haven’t always trusted yourself.” 
Setting up an LPA is particularly important for women, whose greater life expectancy means they make up around 60 per cent of all applications after mental incapacity, Cash says. 
Janet Davies at Symponia, an organisation for later life financial advisers, says you need to act while you are still mentally alert. 
“If the person needing care can no longer make reasoned decisions on their own, then you have to go to court.” 
Last month, simpler LPA forms were introduced, which can be downloaded online at Gov.uk/opg . Appointing an LPA while you are in good health helps to ensure your finances aren’t placed under the control of someone you haven’t always trusted yourself Sarah Cash, head of the tax, trusts and estates team at law firm Hugh James 
Deborah Stone at MyAgeing Parent.com, which offers advice to families caring for elderly relatives, says: “The new forms are easier to follow and faster to complete, so now there is even less excuse for not taking steps to get one set up.” 
You can continue to submit the old forms until January 1, 2016. 
And any existing document drawn up under the old system, including an enduring power of attorney, will remain valid beyond that date. 
Stone adds: “If you appoint your attorney while you still have all your mental faculties, it will be your choice on who makes key decisions on your health and finances should you become too poorly to do so.” 
With dementia affecting one in three people aged 65 and over at some point, there is a real incentive to act. 
She adds: “Mental frailty can set in through a range of other conditions, such as a stroke.” 
At that point, someone will need to decide where you should receive your care and how that is funded. 
Having an LPA in place should your health deteriorate can be hugely reassuring for the individual and their family. 
Daniel Smith, a litigator at DAS Law, says there are two types of LPA. 
One allows the attorney to manage your financial affairs, such as buying and selling property, claiming benefits, dealing with tax affairs, paying bills, and so on. 
Smith says: “The other covers your health and welfare, allowing the attorney to decide on medical matters, what care and treatment you need, as well as dealing with personal correspondence.” 
In practice, many people set up both types of attorney to cover all eventualities. 
Smith says there is a £110 application fee to register an LPA, while legal costs if you have appointed a solicitor can range from £100 to £400 plus VAT. 
If you haven’t set up an LPA in advance you will have to apply to the court of protection in England and Wales, or the sheriff court in Scotland, to become a deputy and make key decisions on their behalf. 
The process can take up to six months and is far more expensive than setting up an LPA. 
There is a £400 application fee, plus another £500 if a hearing is necessary, with legal fees on top. 
Plus you will also have to pay annual supervision fees. 
With luck, the LPA will never be needed at all, but if you do need one, your loved ones will be glad you acted early. Related articles
